column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-07-18 00:00:00	Prelude	1	In my opening remarks
column2: I will address a number of key issues facing Permanent TSB and
column3: in doing so
column4: give an overview of the challenges facing us and the journey we have begun to respond to those challenges.  My colleagues and I appreciate fully the substantial support the Irish taxpayer has given to the group since the financial crisis began.  The crisis in Ireland and across the world over the past four years has been unprecedented.  Without doubt the behaviour of banks
column5: including my own
column6: in the decade or so before 2008 contributed its part to what subsequently unfolded.  The damage which has been caused here in Ireland and in the United Kingdom
column7: Europe and the United States has been profound.  Everyone connected with the bank has paid a heavy price over the past four years.  Our shareholders have been effectively wiped out and our employees
column8: the majority of whom bear no responsibility whatsoever for any of the mistakes which were made
column9: have suffered significant loss of reputation and respect and many have been obliged to leave their jobs.  Most seriously
column10: our customers have suffered financially and in other ways as a consequence of the collapse.  Nevertheless
column11: we fully appreciate that were it not for the very strong support of the Government over that time
column12: the damage would have been much greater and the bank would not have been able to continue in operation.  Consequently
column13: I again wish to put on record my own appreciation
column14: and that of all my colleagues
column15: for this support.I took up my new role as chief executive of the bank on 20 February last or approximately 21 weeks ago.  The days and weeks since then have been extraordinarily busy as
column17: I have worked to address a series of challenges facing the bank.  That work has entailed intensive engagement with the Department of Finance
column20: our staff and with our customers
column21: many of whom I have met directly and others who have written to or telephoned me.  Most have been exceptionally courteous and have shared their views on their own situations and on the general banking climate with great patience and grace.  I will repay that human spirit with an unwavering commitment to rebuild the bank and its reputation.  I wish to express my appreciation for the support I have received from each of these stakeholders and in particular from the team in the banking unit in the Department of Finance
column22: which has worked very closely with us over that time.  My colleagues and I have had three priorities through the past few months.  The first has been to put in place a restructuring plan which would be grounded in clear and objective facts
column23: realistic in its analysis of our current problems clear on the measures we need to take to address them and ambitious in its goal to return the bank to profitability and sustainability without taxpayer support.  A second priority has been to begin to tackle the issue of our comparatively high variable rate mortgage products
column24: while a third priority has been to address what we describe generally as the issue of collections
column26: effectively re-engineering and properly resourcing that function to deal with customers in arrears and to work with customers at risk of going into arrears to prevent that from occurring.  We have made progress on each of these issues.First
column27: let me talk about the restructuring plan.  To understand what we are trying to achieve with our restructuring plan
column29: one cannot overstate the very perilous position of the bank at the start of this year.  As I mentioned earlier
column30: I joined the bank on 20 February and just eight days later
column31: the group issued a profit warning prompted by the need to make provisions for as much as €1.4 billion arising from impairments incurred in 2011.  A couple of weeks later
column32: the bank published its results for 2011 and
column33: largely as a result of those impairments
column34: it posted a loss of approximately €424 million or almost half a billion euro.  That figure would have been much worse had it not been for a one-off gain of approximately €1 billion
column35: which arose out of a liability management exercise in which the junior bondholders shared some of the burden of our crisis and that
column37: has saved the taxpayer about €1 billion.  As members know
column38: the starting point for the bank was very grave.  We began by reviewing in minute detail every aspect of the bank's operations and its financial performance in order that we could ascertain what areas of the bank were working and what were not and
column39: if we could not save the entire integrated operation
column40: whether there was the essence of a so-called "good" Permanent TSB bank that had a viable future and for which there was a real role in the banking landscape and if so
column41: then in what market segment or segments should this "new" Permanent TSB bank compete.In April
column42: we had detailed discussions with the troika to discuss what we had found and in particular to ascertain how we could create a viable bank from within the current Permanent TSB business
column44: for want of a better description
column46: how we would manage those parts of our business which were not viable and which would not be part of the new bank and the reason we believed creating a "new" Permanent TSB would be worthwhile. Let me be very clear in this regard: we considered all the alternatives
column47: including the outright closure of the bank
column48: an alternative which all agreed could lead to a further
column49: significant destruction of value for the taxpayer. Having reviewed the way forward
column51: the troika and I believe that creating a viable
column52: customer-focused and competitive bank at Permanent TSB is a worthy goal and one which will benefit consumers in this country. I believe this market will need strong competitors in the years ahead and a viable Permanent TSB bank can be a powerful presence in that context. At the conclusion of these very difficult discussions
column53: the troika encouraged us to flesh out our restructuring plan and submit it to the European Commission at the end of June. We have now done that.Last week we concluded a second round of discussions with the troika
column54: during which we updated it on the progress made to date and shared the details of the restructuring plan.  While the Government and the troika have been very supportive of the group
column55: they also have been clear that their continued support is entirely dependent on our success in implementing the radical change which they
column57: believe is necessary to create a viable institution.  They also have emphasised that we must work with the authorities to separate the new Permanent TSB from the asset management unit as there is no viability for the group as an integrated legal entity.  Equally importantly
column60: that there will be no sustainable future as long as we are on the life-support system of ECB funding.  To pretend otherwise and to live on the false pretence of deposit and mortgage rates that do not lead to positive returns for the taxpayer
column61: is to subject another generation to taxpayer-funded zombie banks.  Rational banking means generating a return on equity based on a positive net interest margin
column63: the difference between the interest received and the interest paid
column64: a cost base that invests in talent
column66: as well as normalised impairment rates.  The Irish banking market must change.In respect of my own organisation
column67: the troika has made it very clear that time is of the essence.  Our progress will be reviewed and scrutinised when we meet it every quarter
column68: starting in early October.  To begin the process of structural change
column69: we will be unveiling within the next week a detailed restructuring plan for the bank.  We will set out a new operating model which reflects the focused business which we will become and which resets our operating expenses to reflect that fact.  We will run the business through the managerial lens of a new bank and asset management unit
column70: pending a system-driven legal separation.  We will significantly reduce the number of branches from 92 at present.  That said
column71: we will retain a national presence
column72: ensure the network continues to serve the Irish retail banking market better than our competitors and build out the bank's multichannel distribution capability.  We will significantly reconfigure roles and functions in our head office.  We will invest significantly in the core functions of banking
column75: in order that Permanent TSB is respected for its professionalism and rigour.  We will begin to implement the values of performance and accountability so the taxpayer can be confident we are making value-based decisions thus removing
column77: any view that we are entitled to the support of the State.  We need to earn a place back at the heart of society.Unfortunately
column78: there will be some job losses through this change programme.  However
column79: there also will be some new opportunities; in particular in the area of collections
column80: where we plan to double the number of people working in the coming months.  Where jobs are to be lost
column81: we will endeavour to facilitate these through a voluntary severance scheme.  When we roll out the details of this plan
column82: we will be stressing to our colleagues that it is not optional.  It is the minimum required to secure the future of the bank and the redemption of our profession.  Failure to implement it in full and on schedule will jeopardise the future of the bank and the staff within it.  This will not be easy for our staff but I believe they understand the context and on that basis they will realise there are no other options.Our second priority in recent months has been to try to address the issue of the comparatively high interest rates being charged by the bank on variable rate mortgages.  It is important to understand that standard variable rate
column84: mortgages are not our most common mortgage.  The average balances of mortgages on SVR - at approximately €70
column85: 000 - are much lower than is generally understood.  Nevertheless we accept that as a result of decisions taken in 2010 and 2011
column86: Permanent TSB had become an outlier in respect of variable rate mortgages and that is not acceptable.Here again we have made important progress.  At the end of April
column87: within days of receiving positive support from the troika
column88: we announced a unilateral reduction in our variable rates of 50 basis points for home loan mortgages.  Last week
column89: when the ECB reduced its rate by 25 basis points
column90: we announced that we would pass on this reduction
column91: plus a further ten basis points
column93: even as many competitors declined to pass on the reduction itself.  Combined
column94: these two moves have had the effect of reducing our rates by 85 basis points.  It has significantly improved our position compared with our major competitors and we have ended that outlier status.I understand that some believe our rates are still too high.  Based on today's Irish banking market economics - high deposit pricing
column95: high loss rates and high overall funding costs - there is little room to manoeuvre without passing on further burden to the taxpayer.  I will not chase down rates to levels that will negatively impact on the already fragile state of the bank and the economy.  I am not saying there is no room for further reductions but that
column97: it is dependent on us working together to create an environment for a rational banking model.  Let us develop a normalised market and everybody will benefit.I think further clarity on the rates issue is very important.  Our starting point is that we have a responsibility to re-establish a rational banking model in Permanent TSB.  To our mind
column98: a rational banking model starts with the funding side of our balance sheet.  Critics say our lending rates are too high
column99: but one does not run a rational bank by setting out one's lending rates and then hoping one can source one's funding and run one's operating cost base to match.  One identifies one's costs and they dictate what rates one can set.As I mentioned previously
column100: we have three components to our costs.  First is the high costs we face in raising money to finance our mortgage loans
column101: particularly the high costs of deposits in this country
column102: which are only partially reduced by an amount of relatively cheap money being provided temporarily through the ECB.  This is money that is required due to the closure of wholesale markets to the bank but which is not a sustainable source of funding at either price or quantum.  Second is the high costs we face in making provisions for those who cannot repay their loans
column103: and that cost is rising as impairments are rising.  Third is our operating costs - literally what it costs to operate the bank and
column105: provide a realistic return for our shareholder.  I have commented already on the restructuring plan.I have no desire to run a bank where the rates are dictated by what we believe the market can bear.  We have a blended
column106: average cost of funds and that dictates lending product pricing and returns.  I hope and think that as we go forward
column107: the costs I have outlined will reduce
column108: particularly the current irrational cost of deposits.  If they do
column109: I believe we will be able to reduce our variable rates further
column112: then we will come under further pressure to raise rates.  That is how a rational banking system works and that is the type of system we need to re-establish in this market.  Well-regulated competition with this bank playing a core role
column115: reduce taxpayer burden and transfer benefit to the end customer.The third priority has been in respect of collections and arrears.  We are very conscious of the huge toll which the current crisis is exacting on customers who in most cases
column116: through no fault of their own
column117: are struggling or unable to meet their loan repayment commitments.  I regard it as a fundamental responsibility of mine and my colleagues to treat any customers in that position with respect
column119: support and patience.  I believe that is the case in our bank.We are committed to the current MAR process through which we are creating a suite of products to help our customers who have repayment problems
column120: and I believe these can make a very real difference to the challenges facing those customers.  We are also committed to doing all in our power to help our customers avoid getting into arrears in the first instance and
column122: helping them to correct that situation as quickly as possible.On the evidence I have seen since joining the bank
column123: I do not believe sufficient priority has been given to this area since the crisis began.  Thankfully
column124: that now seems to have come to an end.  We are certainly finding that as we engage more deeply with this issue
column125: our customers are responding positively and many are managing to prevent arrears arising or are working with us to minimise the extent of any arrears that are arising.  That is
column127: very positive.Permanent TSB faces many challenges.  The months ahead will see us having to take difficult decisions.  However
column128: the choice facing the people of this country is whether we want to persist with an emasculated banking system which is forever reliant on taxpayer support
column129: lives the lie of artificial pricing and which is incapable of normal business
column130: or whether we want to take the difficult decisions necessary to restore strength and vigour to our banks in order that they can be weaned off taxpayer support and
column132: return to their normal business of banking.  The latter includes the raising of money from deposits at reasonable rates
column133: supplemented by reasonable levels of wholesale funding
column134: which funds that are then lent to borrowers at reasonable rates.I began my career in banking as an 18-year-old junior employee in a branch of Barclays in Rugby in Warwickshire.  In the years since
column135: I have worked in retail banking at many different levels and in different countries
column136: and I have learnt a lot about different organisations and what they can and cannot do.  Everything I have learned since I came to Ireland tells me that
column138: there is something very special at the heart of this bank.  In particular
column139: I have been hugely impressed by the dedication and quality of employees across the bank
column140: and their desire to do the right thing by the taxpayer
column141: shareholder and customer.  These are good people who want the bank to be seen as an institution known for good products
column143: good prices and good values.  Of course
column146: will be the judge of whether we can regain that trust.  All I ask is that we are given a chance to do that.I firmly believe that if we can get beyond the current crisis
column147: there is the potential to create a new Permanent TSB bank which will be customer focused
column149: and a force for positive competition in this marketplace.  I believe that will be a good thing for this country.  That is the singular goal on which everyone working in the bank is concentrated.  I look forward to playing my role in helping to bring that about.

column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-07-18 00:00:00	Prelude	44	I was contacted by a constituent who is an existing customer of Permanent TSB and was previously paying 3.1% on a two year fixed rate mortgage. column2: a two year fixed rate of 7.25% or a five year fixed rate of 8.75%.  I mean no disrespect but it is not good enough that Mr. Masding does not know the rates. Other financial institutions would allow her to benefit from that but she gets no benefit from Mr. Masding's institution.  A new customer can get a rate of 3.69% but she was quoted 4.35% as an existing customer.  There is clearly a divergence.Mr. Masding stated:I understand that some believe our rates are still too high.  Based on today's Irish banking market economics - high deposit pricing
column3: high loss rates and high overall funding costs - there is little room to manoeuvre without passing on further burden to the taxpayer.  I will not chase down rates to levels that will negatively impact on the already fragile state of the bank and the economy.The rates that Permanent TSB is charging are negatively impacting on the direct economy.  It was recapitalised by the Irish taxpayer on the basis of being able to provide additional lending.  The three elements of funding are deposits
column4: the ECB and wholesale funding rates.  Will Mr. Masding explain what the typical tracker mortgage is paying at present and what Permanent TSB pays on deposits and for wholesale funding
column5: on average?  What proportion of its funding comes from the ECB?Mr. Masding noted that both segments of its mortgage book are loss making. Tracker loans comprise between 55% and 58% of the overall loan book
column6: which means in excess of 40% of mortgages are on variable or fixed rates.The devil is always in the detail.  We need a better understanding of the blended rate of 2.2%.  What percentage of that funding comes from the very low rate offered by the ECB?  I accept that Permanent TSB wants to return to a being a viable and sustainable bank but the taxpayer is carrying much of the load.  We are in this together. How can it make a loss on variable rate loans which are in excess of 2% above the blended rate?The rate charged to my constituent is 100 basis points higher than would be charged to a new customer. column5: there were five
column6: the most recent of which was a reduction ten weeks ago.  However
column7: the four to which the Deputy referred pertained to increases and the maximum increase we levied outside of any ECB increase was 1%. column8: the objective of increasing the net interest income as a result of moving outside of ECB increases had been to attempt to ensure the capital base of the organisation was strong enough to absorb the additional stress test conducted by BlackRock.  Obviously
column9: this did not happen but this was the intent behind it.  However
column10: this happened in advance of any recapitalisation of the organisation.  Consequently
column11: I do not seek brownie points for this but subsequent to the recapitalisation
column12: the only change made outside of an ECB rate change is the one we made ten weeks ago
column13: which was a reduction of 50 basis points.  Based on this
column14: it would not be correct to link any standard variable rate increases or additional charges to customers to attempts to keep that capital base shored up.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-07-18 00:00:00	Prelude	310	I would like Mr. Masding to comment on one thing that baffles me
column2: not just in his bank but with all of the banks we have recapitalised.  What precisely is the relationship between his bank's policies and the Government
column3: which represents the people
column4: which has rapidly recapitalised Permanent TSB?  Frankly
column5: I find it frustrating at this stage that we have recapitalised Permanent TSB and kept it in business
column6: when those of us on the left argued that we should have nationalised the banks immediately as a response to this crisis.  We often get the response from the Government: "Oh
column7: but the banks are nationalised".  The very same Government then gives out about the behaviour of banks and essentially says it has no control over the banks' policies even though it has effectively refinanced them.What is Mr. Masding's relationship to the Government
column8: which represents the people
column9: and to the troika?  To what extent does the Government or the troika tell him what to do?  I am thinking in particular about the European Central Bank.  On a number of occasions in the Dáil I have tried to highlight guidelines issued by the ECB at the outset of the crisis
column10: which I frankly believe are key to a lot of what is going on.  At that time
column11: the ECB warned governments that they should avoid nationalisation if possible
column12: but if it were necessary to nationalise
column13: no bank must divert from the central orientation on profit maximisation and a commercial approach to banking.  It should not be deflected on to social goals or wider macro-economic goals.  To my mind
column14: that is the heart of the problem because I think Permanent TSB should be diverted on to those issues
column15: particularly because the bank is only in existence because of public money.  In my opinion
column16: the bank is there to represent the public interest and not just shareholder interest.So can Mr. Masding comment on what his relationship is with the public authorities and the troika?  To what extent do they have any say or influence over his bank's policies
column17: including the sort of policies we are debating and discussing here?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-07-18 00:00:00	Prelude	311	We run the bank as an independent organisation.  I am accountable to a board of directors for the decisions that I make.  As an institution
column2: we run a standard model.  We have a shareholder
column3: which is the Government
column4: and I meet with that shareholder regularly.  I am accountable to that shareholder for delivering the strategy and plan which has been agreed by the shareholder and the troika.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2012-07-18 00:00:00	Prelude	317	Let me go back to what I said.  In the model that we are operating

column3: then in a market the shareholder is the ultimate decision maker.  In terms of how that works
